original_title: Sri Lanka tax body warns evaders; explores actions
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s main tax collection body is considering action against those who do not pay their tax dues despite being eligible after the latest tax reforms, a top official said.
Ranjith Hapuarachchi, the Commissioner General of Inland Revenue Department (IRD) said the number of tax files have not increased in line with the latest tax reforms.

“The threshold level for tax has been reduced from 3 million rupees to 1.2 million or 100,000 per month. This means, we should see an increase in the tax files. But we haven’t seen that,” Hapuarachchi told a media briefing on Thursday (13).
“We will wait for some time to see if people would open tax files voluntarily. If it does not happen, we may go to the next level of actions,” he said without elaborating.

President Ranil Wickremesinghe introduced tax reforms to boost the government revenue after the island nation’s economic crisis led to an unprecedented political crisis, which forced former president Gotabaya Rajapaksa and former prime minister Mahinda Rajapaksa to resign in controversial circumstances.

State sector trade unions and private sector employees resisted the tax hikes, but they had no option other than complying with the law because their taxes were under Pay-As-You-Earn (PAYE) and deducted by their employer.
However, government officials say there are a large number of people in the informal sector who have been evading taxes because they are not traced by a formal financial network.
“We have measures to trace these tax evaders and we are already doing it,” Hapuarachchi told the EconomyNext.
He said the IRD asks people to open files after assessing their vehicle ownership or some assets similar to that.
“If they don’t open, we will file a case against them and they have to prove that they are not eligible to pay taxes.”

In the latest tax proposals, the government has urged Sri Lankan citizens aged more than 18 years to open tax files while the State Finance Minister has said Individuals who open fresh income tax accounts under the latest tax proposals will not be asked questions on tax returns not filed in prior years.

Sri Lanka has poor tax payments records with only 293,305 tax files existing out of 5.8 million households in 2020. Out of them, only 120,000 had filed returns in 2021 and 28,621 individuals had paid less than 10,000 rupees, 22,368 had paid 100,000 rupees or less, and 5,493 had paid 500,000 rupees or less, government data showed. (Colombo/July 14/2023)
